title: Charles Trevanion
text:
Charles Trevanion, 1594 to 1660, was an English landowner and politician, who was <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">MP</a> for <a href="Cornwall%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Cornwall</a> in 1625 and <a href="High%20Sheriff%20of%20Cornwall">Sheriff</a> from 1633 to 1634. He supported the <a href="Cavalier">Royalist</a> cause during the <a href="First%20English%20Civil%20War">First English Civil War</a>, his eldest son <a href="John%20Trevanion">John Trevanion</a> being killed in 1643.
Personal details.
Charles Trevanion was born around 1594, eldest son of Charles Trevanion (died 1601) of <a href="Caerhays%20Castle">Caerhays Castle</a> and his wife Joan Wichalse ( 1568-1598). One of the largest landowners in <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, his father controlled several seats in <a href="Parliament%20of%20England">Parliament</a>, served as <a href="Vice-Admiral%20of%20Cornwall">Vice-Admiral of Cornwall</a> and was <a href="High%20Sheriff%20of%20Cornwall">High Sheriff of Cornwall</a> in 1596. When he died in 1601, Trevanion inherited nearly 8,000 <a href="acre">acre</a>s of land around the village of <a href="St%20Michael%20Caerhays">St Michael Caerhays</a>.
Sometime before 1613, he married Amia Mallet, daughter of Sir John Mallet of Enmore; they had two sons and a daughter, including <a href="John%20Trevanion">John Trevanion</a> (1613-1643), who was killed in the <a href="Storming%20of%20Bristol">Storming of Bristol</a>.
Career.
Trevanion attended <a href="Oriel%20College%2C%20Oxford">Oriel College, Oxford</a> in 1611 and became a local <a href="Justice%20of%20the%20Peace">Justice of the Peace</a> in 1617. Elected for <a href="Cornwall%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Cornwall</a> in <a href="Useless%20Parliament">1625</a>, he did not stand again but his extensive estates gave him influence over the Parliamentary seats of <a href="Grampound%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Grampound</a>, <a href="Tregony%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Tregony</a> and <a href="St%20Mawes%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">St Mawes</a>. This fact made him a substantial player in Cornish politics for the next thirty years.
Although Trevanion supported the Parliamentary opposition in the debate over the <a href="Petition%20of%20Right">Petition of Right</a>, his son John was one of 59 MPs named as "betrayers of their country" in May 1641 for voting against the <a href="Bill%20of%20Attainder">Bill of Attainder</a> for <a href="Thomas%20Wentworth%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Strafford">Strafford</a>.
